title-group.article-title: Cesarean delivery may increase the risk of multiple sclerosis

article-meta.aff: 1Isfahan Research Committee of Multiple Sclerosis (IRCOMS), Iran
2Neuroimmunology Unit, Centre for Neuroscience & Trauma, Blizard Institute of Cell and Molecular Science, Barts and the London School of Medicine and Dentistry, UK
3Medical School, Isfahan University of Medical Sciences, Iran
4Department of Neurology, Al-Zahra Hospital, Isfahan University of Medical Sciences, Iran
5Department of Neurology, Louisiana State University Health Sciences Center, USA
6Department of Statistics, Faculty of Basic Science, University of Mazandaran, Iran

author-notes.corresp: Amir-Hadi Maghzi, Isfahan Research Committee of Multiple Sclerosis (IRCOMS), Multiple Sclerosis Clinic, Al-Zahra hospital, Isfahan University of Medical Sciences, Soffeh Street, Isfahan 81744, Iran. Email: Maghzi@edc.mui.ac.ir and a.h.maghzi@qmul.ac.uk

abstract.p: Background: Prenatal and perinatal factors are believed to contribute to the risk of developing multiple sclerosis (MS).
Objective: This study was designed to evaluate whether mode of delivery (vaginal versus cesarean section), as a perinatal factor, affects susceptibility to MS.

Methods: MS patients were recruited from the MS registry of Isfahan Multiple Sclerosis Society (IMSS) and were compared with their healthy siblings. Data regarding mode of delivery, birth order, and gestation week of birth were obtained through a specially designed questionnaire. Preterm or post term deliveries were excluded. We used conditional logistic regression statistics and adjusted for gender and birth order.

Results: This study included 1349 participants (449 MS patients and 900 controls). Subjects who were born by cesarean section had significant risk of MS (odds ratio, OR = 2.51; 95% confidence interval, CI: 1.43–4.41; p = 0.001). There was significant MS risk for females who were born by cesarean section (OR = 2.69, 95% CI: 1.30–5.58; p = 0.008), but not for males (OR = 2.25, 95% CI: 0.90–5.63; p = 0.082). The mean age at onset was lower in MS patients born by cesarean section (24.58 ± 6.33) compared with that of patients born by vaginal delivery (27.59 ± 7.97; p = 0.041). There was no significant difference between the two groups for birth order (p = 0.417).

Conclusion: Our results suggest that those born by vaginal delivery are at a lower risk of subsequent MS. These preliminary findings will need to be addressed in a much larger and preferably prospective study.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Several studies point towards the significance of environmental risk factors in triggering the onset of multiple sclerosis (MS).1 A maternal parent of origin has been suggested for MS, and it is presumed that prenatal and perinatal factors could explain this observation.2 Several prenatal and perinatal factors have been studied but only few have been shown to influence the susceptibility to MS.3,4

By studying MS patients and their healthy siblings who experience closely similar maternal effects, it would be easier to pinpoint different maternal effects which lead to the disease, although in this case overmatching might reduce the statistical power to detect the difference.

It has been suggested that cesarean delivery might be associated with a greater risk of developing immune-mediated diseases such as asthma and allergies, and autoimmune diseases such as Crohn’s disease.5,6 This prompted us to examine whether mode of delivery as a perinatal factor affects the susceptibility to MS in an Iranian cohort of MS patients and their healthy siblings.

sec.title: Patients and methods
sec.p: MS patients were recruited from the Isfahan Multiple Sclerosis Society (IMSS) database. Details of the IMSS database have been published earlier.7,8 The study protocol was approved by local ethics committee and participants provided signed informed consents.

For this sibling case-control study patients with a diagnosis of definite MS and their healthy siblings were recruited. Participants were asked about their mode of delivery (normal vaginal delivery or cesarean section), gestation week of their birth and birth order through a specially designed questionnaire which also gathered demographic data of both MS patients and healthy siblings. If delivery was preterm (< 37 weeks) or post term (≥ 42 weeks), they were excluded. If participants did not know the answer to these questions they were asked to contact their parents and complete and return the questionnaires later. If there was a missing value for a patient both the patient and the healthy siblings were excluded from the study. We excluded those siblings with suspected neurological symptoms attributable to MS or a confirmed diagnosis of MS. If the index case did not have healthy siblings or no siblings at all, we included only the patient.

Data were analyzed using PASW Statistics 18. We used conditional logistic regression statistics and adjusted for the gender and birth order. Independent samples t-test was used to compare mean values and Mann–Whitney U test was undertaken to compare birth order between the two groups. All tests were two tailed and a p value of less than 0.05 was considered as the significance threshold.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: We surveyed 1920 participants but for the purpose of this study 1349 (449 MS patients and 900 of their healthy siblings) had complete data. Of the 449 MS patients, 351 (78.2%) were female and 98 (21.8%) were male. The mean age at study enrollment of MS patients was 32.69 ± 8.80 years, and the mean age at onset of the disease was 27.38 ± 7.90 years. There were 83.3% with a relapsing–remitting disease course, 2.9% with a primary progressive MS and 13.8% had a secondary progressive course. Among the 900 controls, 415 (46.1%) were female and 485 (53.9%) were male. The mean age at enrollment of healthy siblings was 32.90 ± 9.85 years.

Table 1 shows the odds of MS for type of delivery adjusted for birth order and gender among all patients and among males and females separately. There was significantly increased risk of MS for females born by cesarean section (odds ratio, OR = 2.695; p = 0.008), but not for males (OR = 2.253; p = 0.082).

caption.p: Relation between delivery mode and MS for all participants (adjusted for gender and birth order) and separated for males and females (adjusted for birth order)

sec.p: The mean age at onset of MS patients born by cesarean section (24.58 ± 6.33) compared with that of patients born by vaginal delivery (27.59 ± 7.97) was significantly lower (p = 0.041). There was no significant difference between the two groups for birth order (p = 0.417).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Our study suggests that there may be a link between the mode of delivery and susceptibility to MS. Indeed this study showed that subjects who were born by cesarean had a higher risk of developing MS and this risk is more prominent in females.

MS is a complex neurological trait with a maternal effect shown by several studies.2 Intrauterine, pre- and perinatal factors, may affect susceptibility to the disease.1,4 Gardener and colleagues investigated the role of several prenatal and perinatal factors on risk of MS.3 They suggested modest associations with subsequent risk of MS for late initiation of prenatal care, lack of parental cohabitation at birth, elevated maternal pre-pregnancy body mass index and maternal diabetes.3 A possible risk of MS was suggested for children of women exposed prenatally to diethylstilbestrol (DES).3 Birth weight, preterm birth, mother–child blood group incompatibility, infant day care attendance, congenital abnormalities and parental age are probably not associated with the risk of MS.9-14

It is proposed that early life infections may protect against autoimmune disorders such as MS (hygiene hypotheses). In support of this concept, one study found that pediatric MS patients compared with controls were less likely to have been exposed to herpes viruses.15 Thus, vaginal delivery might be protective against MS by exposing the child to vaginal flora and possibly herpes viruses.

Another explanation for our observations is that cesarean section may alter gut mictoflora in the newborns,16 and gut flora have been shown to influence the development and course of experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE; an animal model for MS).17 Caesarean section in animals has been shown to alter immune system function, which might be another explanation for our observation.18 Moreover, DNA-methylation has been thought to be higher in infants delivered by cesarean section than in infants vaginally born, thus mode of delivery could have an impact on epigenetic differences.19 In the case of MS, epigenetic alterations have been suggested to play a role in the disease pathophysiology.20

As supported by the birth month effect, maternal vitamin D deficiency might increase the risk of MS in the offspring.4 Of note is that maternal vitamin D deficiency has also been shown to be associated with increased rate of cesarean section.21

The primary strengths of this study are the use of a large cohort of MS patients and their healthy siblings who share common maternal effects as the controls. All preterm and post term deliveries were excluded to avoid the effect of preterm and post term births as confounders on the mode of delivery. Limitations of this study include: (i) exposure misclassification was inevitable due to recall bias; (ii) since our study used siblings of MS patients as controls then the effect of overmatching in reducing the statistical power cannot be excluded; however, our study beyond this effect could show a significant difference between the two groups; (iii) there is a possibility that some obstetric indications for cesarean section or complications therefrom might be responsible for this effect, and therefore further studies should also take into account maternal indications for cesarean. A strength of this study was adjustment for birth order, since birth order of the sibling with cesarean delivery determines the mode of delivery of any subsequent siblings. The mean age of MS patients and their siblings was nearly equal and this would exclude the confounding from temporal changes in the rate of cesarean.

In conclusion, the present study shows that MS patients compared with their healthy siblings are more frequently delivered by caesarean section. However, these results should be confirmed in large preferably prospective cohorts and further research is required to shed light on the potential underlying mechanism(s).

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.

sec.p: The authors declare no conflicts of interest.
